Dear Mr. Berndtson,

Mr. S. Evan's reply above is a little terse but he makes the key point that the 39 % efficiency number is actually pretty good when you look at heat engines operating under Carnot's law.

And almost all our commercial energy conversion devices are heat engines.

The absolute best you can do, with a heat engine, is the Carnot efficiency

nu = 1 - (Tc/Th)

where Tc = the absolute temperature of the heat sink and Th = the absolute temperature of the heat source.

And actual efficiency is usually a lot less due to internal friction, incomplete combustion, and a host of other real world factors.

The first steam engine, by Savory, was only about 3% efficient. Newcomen's engine was about 5% efficient.

James Watt and Matthew Bolton revolutionized the world by upping the steam engine's thermal efficiency to about 10% with their separate condenser and continuously-heated cylinder.

By the 1880's the Corliss steam engine was still only 20% efficient.

But present-day gasoline engines in cars are even worse, about 12% thermally efficient in combined urban-highway driving cycles. Diesel engines are about 18%.

Modern combined-cycle power plants can approach an overal thermal efficiency of about 55%.

The only energy conversion devices more efficient than that are fuel cells, which, when run on hydrogen, can approach 70% efficiency.

Reducing wasted energy is the constant occupation of all good engineers. But the lights need to stay on while we do it.

Reply to Dana:

You are quite mistaken. There are advantages to molten salt reactors, but like all other reactors fueled with U-238, they make plutonium which is not all fissioned. That leaves us having to sequester the Pu-239 for 240,000 years. If you mean thorium to U-233 breeder reactors, they would be preferable, but the uranium has a half life of 259,000 years.

Dr. John Miller
@NuclearReporter

Your first problem is that you're focused entirely on the current way of running nuclear fission reactors: pressurized light water. While that is indeed all we (and the Japanese and the Germans) have in current production in the US, the French have other technology in production. The US used to have a very nice Molten Salt Reactor The thing about MSR is that you don't have fuel pellets and if the reactor pumps lose power the thing just stops. There is no steam to explode. there is not the long-term (tens of thousands of years) radioactive waste storage, the wast is les in weight and volume and decays in a few hundred years.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molten_salt_reactor

Even with today's light water reactors they do not produce air pollution during use unlike fossiel-fuel power plants. Yes, there is the problem of radioactive waste -- but fossil fuel plants produce air pollution during operation and leave solid waste ash behind after burning. Coal ash is quite toxic! See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coal_ash and check the references there as well.

One sure way to provide those three things is for developing nations to reach the level of development necessary that their populations do not exist in poverty.  One of the most direct ways to make that happen is for them to have dependable energy supplies.  And there is your Catch 22, and it's quite a catch.  According to the Energy Information Agency report from 2009 global energy demand was expected to rise by 44% by 2030 with 70% of that increase happening in developing countries.  (I haven't read the most recent reports, but I believe their projections are similar.). We can reduce population growth, but it will take a lot of energy to make it happen.  How do we provide that energy without it causing GHG emissions to accelerate?

Actually there are a couple forms of energy we exploit that don't come from the sun: geothermal and nuclear, both of which use heat created by fission.  Neither of those resources is part of the solar balance sheet.

There's no such thing as a free lunch: every way to produce energy has a cost. But in the long run the costs of burning fossil fuels and of nuclear energy are the unacceptable ones: fossil fuels because they destroy the environment, and nuclear energy because it will poison the globe for millennia. How could humans be so stupid as to create nuclear waste with no plan for what to do with it? Even animals know not to foul their nests (don't defecate where you eat and sleep).

All energy on the Earth comes from the sun. Some came years ago and was stored as fossil fuel or geo-heat. More comes every year. Currently we are using more than we harvest from annual sunshine so we're dipping into past reserves -- and using them up rapidly, at ever greater environmental cost. We need to move towards a situation that is more in balance, ie where total energy use is closer to annual solar harvest. That means increasing "renewables", yes, but it also means cutting total use, and I don't see us as likely to do that unless world population declines dramatically.

Are we serious? I don't have the figures handy, but I remember a study that said the US could cut it's energy use significantly by two simple measures: turning off lights that are not in use, and cutting speed limits to 45 mph. We groan about global warming, but we aren't willing to stop lighting up the night sky and traveling at 70 mph, so we ease our consciences by recycling.

28% of the US population graduates from college - yet the benefits in the last 15 years have accrued only to the top 1%. College graduates are better off than those lacking high-school or post-high-school education - but not by enough to justify the high costs of higher education. Furthermore - 40% of college graduates in recent years have been hired into positions that do not require college education. So, where their eduction gave them competitive advantage in the labor market - it does not reflect in their income (compared to college grads in past years rather than compared to high-school grads today). Reliance on employment in either the (slated to be shrunk) healthcare sector, or the already shrinking public sector is no real solution to an ever growing gap between the number of those that  want to work full time and those that do.
